title: Frank Thomas (outfielder)
text:
Frank Joseph Thomas (born June 11, 1929) is an <a href="Americans">American</a> former <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="left%20fielder">left fielder</a>, <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a> and <a href="third%20baseman">third baseman</a> who played in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) for the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Pirates">Pittsburgh Pirates</a> (–), <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a> (), <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a> (1960–1961, 1966), <a href="Milwaukee%20Braves">Milwaukee Braves</a> (1961, 1965), <a href="New%20York%20Mets">New York Mets</a> (–), <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a> (1964–1965) and <a href="Houston%20Astros">Houston Astros</a> (1965). He batted and threw right-handed and was listed as tall and .
Born in <a href="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a> and of <a href="Lithuanians">Lithuanian</a> descent, he attended high school at <a href="Our%20Lady%20of%20Mount%20Carmel%20Secondary%20School">Our Lady of Mount Carmel Secondary School</a>. As a teenager he attended a <a href="seminary">seminary</a> in <a href="Niagara%20Falls%2C%20Ontario">Niagara Falls, Ontario</a>, and he studied for the <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> <a href="priesthood%20in%20the%20Catholic%20Church">priesthood</a> for 4 years before entering pro baseball. 
Career.
Thomas signed with the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Pirates">Pittsburgh Pirates</a> as an amateur free agent in 1947. He debuted with the Pirates in 1951. With the Pirates, he made three All-Star Games, and finished fourth in the voting for Most Valuable Player in 1958, when he batted .281, finished second in the <a href="National%20League">National League</a> to <a href="Ernie%20Banks">Ernie Banks</a> with 35 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s, and had 109 RBIs. Thomas appeared on the cover of the July 28, 1958 issue of "<a href="Sports%20Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a>". He also won his only <a href="MLB%20Player%20of%20the%20Month">NL Player of the Month award</a> in June, batting .275 with 9 home runs and 29 RBI. On August 16, 1958, Thomas hit three home runs in a 13-4 rout of the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a>.
In 1959, he was traded by the Pirates with <a href="Whammy%20Douglas">Whammy Douglas</a>, <a href="Jim%20Pendleton">Jim Pendleton</a> and <a href="John%20Powers%20%28baseball%29">John Powers</a> to the <a href="Cincinnati%20Redlegs">Cincinnati Redlegs</a> for <a href="Smoky%20Burgess">Smoky Burgess</a>, <a href="Harvey%20Haddix">Harvey Haddix</a> and <a href="Don%20Hoak">Don Hoak</a>. Due to a shattered nerve in the thumb of his right hand, Thomas home run output fell from 35 to 12 in 1959. Following the season, he was traded by the Redlegs to the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a> for <a href="Bill%20Henry%20%28baseball%2C%20born%201927%29">Bill Henry</a>, <a href="Lou%20Jackson">Lou Jackson</a> and <a href="Lee%20Walls">Lee Walls</a>. In 1961, he was traded by Cubs to the <a href="Milwaukee%20Braves%20%281953%E2%80%9365%29">Milwaukee Braves</a> for <a href="Mel%20Roach">Mel Roach</a>.
Thomas was traded by the Braves with a <a href="player%20to%20be%20named%20later">player to be named later</a> (<a href="Rick%20Herrscher">Rick Herrscher</a>) to the <a href="New%20York%20Mets">New York Mets</a> for a player to be named later (<a href="Gus%20Bell">Gus Bell</a>) and cash. Despite the team's <a href="1962%20New%20York%20Mets%20season">historically poor inaugural season</a>, Thomas led the expansion Mets with 34 home runs and 94 RBIs. His home run mark would last as a Mets' team record until 1975, when <a href="Dave%20Kingman">Dave Kingman</a> broke it.
In 1964, Thomas was traded by the New York Mets to the <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a> for <a href="Wayne%20Graham">Wayne Graham</a>, <a href="Gary%20Kroll">Gary Kroll</a> and cash. He was purchased by the <a href="Houston%20Astros">Houston Astros</a> from the Phillies in July 1965 shortly after hitting <a href="Dick%20Allen">Richie Allen</a> with a bat, but was traded to Braves for a <a href="player%20to%20be%20named%20later">player to be named later</a> (Mickey Sinnerud) in September 1965. In an hour-long interview aired December 15, 2009, on the MLB Network's Studio 42 with Bob Costas, Allen asserted that he and Thomas are in fact good friends now.
On April 5, 1966, Thomas was released by the Braves. He signed with the Cubs on May 14, 1966, and after recording five plate appearances without a hit, he was released on June 4, 1966.
In a 16-season career, Thomas posted a .266 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> with 286 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s and 962 <a href="run%20batted%20in">RBI</a>s in 1766 <a href="games%20played">games</a>. He was larger than the average player of his time, and known for his opinionated nature. One of his nicknames as a player was "The Big Donkey."
Family life.
Thomas and his wife, Dolores, were married for over 60 years and had eight children before he became a widower. He has 12 grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.
